В СК по Ленобласти обсудили итоги работы за девять месяцев 2019 года
02 Nov 2019, 10:46 by Алексей Громов

В Следственном управлении СК России по Ленобласти прошло заседание коллегии по итогам работы за девять месяцев 2019 года. На нем стало известно, что следователи Следственного управления повысили эффективность работы по преступлениям.

В Следственном управлении Следственного комитета России по Ленобласти прошло заседание коллегии по итогам работы за девять месяцев 2019 года. об этом рассказали в пресс-службе регионального СУ СК РФ.
Участники подвели итоги работы в том числе по решению задач, поставленных Председателем Следственного комитета России, касающихся оперативного и качественного расследования уголовных дел, соблюдения законности, обеспечения принятия законных и обоснованных решений, соблюдения прав граждан на доступ к правосудию при приеме, регистрации и проверке сообщений о преступлениях.
Так, с начала 2019 года следователи Следственного управления добились улучшения показателей по обеспечению разумных сроков уголовного судопроизводства, увеличили процент возмещения ущерба, причиненного преступлениями и повысили эффективность работы по преступлениям, совершенным в прошлые годы.
Однако были отмечены и недостатки в деятельности некоторых следственных отделов, связанные с качеством расследования и другие упущения в работе. В связи с этим были приняты организационные и дисциплинарные меры.
В работе коллегии под председательством руководителя Следственного управления Сергея Тихоновича Сазина также приняли участие члены коллегии следственного управления, сотрудники аппарата и руководители территориальных следственных отделов.
Накануне НЕВСКИЕ НОВОСТИ писали министр внутренних дел РФ генерал полиции Владимир Колокольцев провел заседание коллегии МВД России. Участники обсудили меры, направленные на совершенствование работы по выявлению, раскрытию и расследованию преступлений. Тогда сообщалось, что, по информации ведомства, число противоправных деяний, совершенных с применением информационных технологий, увеличилось в два раза, а с начала этого года – почти на 70 %.

A philosophical reading of The Little Prince
02 Nov 2019, 10:08 by Diego Rojas Ajmad

The Little Prince is not just a work for children. It is a story full of wise questions that can serve as a stimulus, at any age and stage of existence.




If The Prince of Nicholas Machiavelli is the classic manual of political theory for the government of others, The Little Prince, by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, is the perfect manual for the government of oneself. More than a matter of sizes and diminutives, the difference between a prince and a little prince focuses on the perspective from which to understand the world. A smaller prince, according to the already classic French work, manages to see what the greatest prince cannot: the essentials without the help of the eyes. I remember a text by Manuel García Morente, Preliminary Lessons in Philosophy, 1938, in which The author emphasized the need for the child's gaze as an essential condition for practicing the search for truth. Garcia Morente said:





To approach philosophy, to enter the territory of philosophy, a first mood is absolutely indispensable. It is absolutely essential that the aspiring philosopher take good charge of bringing to his state a childish disposition. He who wants to be a philosopher will need to become childish, childish, become like the little boy. ”


Whoever wants to understand the world, who wants to find some meaning in reality and actions, according to García Morente, must do as the little boy who says he does not understand anything and therefore asks tirelessly, because for him everything is a mysterious problem that amazing and deserves to be revealed.Antoine de Saint-Exupéry (1900-1944) endorses this idea in The Little Prince and turns it into a thematic line that stands out throughout the short work: the adult-child opposition. With this argument, present from the dedication to the last page, we are invited to be spectators of a fascinating story that plays with the possibility of being the delirium of a sunstroke, the overflowed imagination of a person facing a borderline situation or the inexplicable contact With a being from another world. Precisely, so different are the worlds of the adult and those of the child that the union between one and the other is represented as a story of extraterrestrial encounter. Published in 1943, The Little Prince is the exaltation of the child's gaze over that of the adult. But what does it mean to look at the world from the eyes of a child? What privileges and advantages does this lead in a world that constantly recommends us to grow and mature in order to face the calamities of life? In case we have forgotten, to assume the perspective of a child is to recover the astonishment, the question that unceasingly questions and destabilizes the instituted, the curiosity that makes us find the unexpected without putting any cat in danger of death. When a child looks at the The world finds that the important thing for an adult is actually something banal and the inconsequential contains the most important. This kind of investment of values makes us realize that what is considered natural and obvious is nothing more than a convention that tradition, family, institutions, prejudices and ideologies have forged on our way of being and doing in the world . When the new innocent and questioning perspective of the little prince appears, it ends up turning normality and prejudice into an abyss of uncertainty. Thus, The Little Prince makes us think again about power, friendship, love, identity, body and spirit, knowledge, work, earnings, dangers represented in baobabs, life and death and everything that in the adult world we think we have very well defined, measured and thought. The Little Prince is not just a work for children. It is a story full of wise questions that can serve as a stimulus, at any age and stage of existence, to stop and reflect on what we have done with our lives. In the hands of a passionate teacher, teacher or reading club coordinator, this little book can be used to achieve what you want with all reading: knowing others and ourselves. "Everyday weaves cobwebs in our eyes", he arrived to say the Argentine poet Oliverio Girondo. The little prince helps us, as he does with the tiny volcanoes of his planet, to clear the view of the cobwebs of prejudices and conventions to recover the perfect vision of the lost kingdom of childhood. Other pages- Andrés Mariño Palacio. He was a writer of enigmatic and curious life who was born in Maracaibo on November 3, 1927. He cultivated the story, the novel and journalism, and left published three books that are today rarities of the Venezuelan literature. Those three books are: The limit of boredom (1946, short stories), The Joyful Evicted (1948, novel) and Battle towards the dawn (1958, novel). He was a voracious reader and his generation partners admired his ability to learn about countless works and authors. In 1948, at 21, he lost his mental faculties and was held in a sanatorium. He died of a heart attack on October 30, 1966. Rafael Pineda compiled some of his essays, scattered in magazines and other periodicals, and edited with them in 1967 at the National Institute of Culture and Fine Arts the book entitled Essays. This book contains impressive samples of criticism and reflection about national and world letters and, as a gift for readers, also includes a facsimile reproduction of their notes in the sanatorium.
